title: Necrotizing Enterocolitis
diagnosis_topic: Intestinal ischemia and inflammation leading to necrosis in preterm neonates
setup_script: A 30-week premature neonate on day 10 of life develops abdominal distension, feeding intolerance and bloody stools. He was previously on full enteral feeds.

dynamic_flow.reply: Temperature instability (35.8 C), HR 175 bpm, episodes of apnea and bradycardia.
Distended, shiny abdomen with tenderness and decreased bowel sounds; erythema of abdominal wall may be present.
CBC shows leukocytosis with left shift or leukopenia, thrombocytopenia; metabolic acidosis and elevated lactate.
Pneumatosis intestinalis and portal venous gas; may see pneumoperitoneum if perforation occurs.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discontinues enteral feeds and places nasogastric decompression
dynamic_flow.reply: Decompress bowel and prevent further distension.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates broad-spectrum antibiotics (ampicillin, gentamicin, metronidazole)
dynamic_flow.reply: Cover Gram-positive, Gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides fluid resuscitation and parenteral nutrition
dynamic_flow.reply: Maintain perfusion and support growth while bowel rests.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident monitors for signs of perforation
dynamic_flow.reply: Clinical deterioration, abdominal wall erythema or pneumoperitoneum necessitate emergent laparotomy.
Resection of necrotic bowel with creation of ostomy; second-look surgery may be necessary.
Rapid progression to shock, DIC and death.
Short bowel syndrome, strictures and neurodevelopmental delays.
Explain severity, need for prolonged hospitalization and possibility of surgery.

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of necrotizing enterocolitis in preterm infants
Management with bowel rest, gastric decompression and broad-spectrum antibiotics
Monitoring for and promptly addressing perforation or necrosis requiring surgery
Supportive care including fluid resuscitation and parenteral nutrition
Counseling families about prognosis and long-term complications
